story:
Once upon a time, in a small village nestled at the foot of Mount Ararat, there lived a kind and gentle father named Ashot and his curious and adventurous daughter, Anahit. Anahit was known throughout the village for her beautiful dark hair, her bright and intelligent eyes, and her boundless imagination.

One day, Anahit came to her father with a question that had been bothering her for some time. "Father," she asked, "why does the sun rise and set every day?"

Ashot smiled at his daughter and took her hand. "Come, Anahit," he said, "let me tell you a story that my father told me, and his father before him."

And so, Ashot began to tell Anahit the story of the Sun Maiden, a beautiful and powerful goddess who lived in a palace of gold and light at the top of Mount Ararat. The Sun Maiden was responsible for bringing light and warmth to the world every day, but she grew tired and needed to rest.

"So, every night, the Sun Maiden retreats to her palace and closes the door, plunging the world into darkness," Ashot explained. "But as the world sleeps, the Sun Maiden's servants, the Stars, come out to play, scattering their light across the sky."

"And then, when the world is ready to wake up again, the Sun Maiden opens the door to her palace and steps out into the sky, bringing light and warmth back to the world," he continued.

Anahit listened to the story with wide eyes, her imagination running wild with images of the Sun Maiden and her palace of gold and light.

"But father, why does the Sun Maiden need to rest?" she asked.

Ashot thought for a moment before answering. "Perhaps it is because even the most powerful beings need time to recharge and refresh," he said. "Just like you, Anahit, need your sleep every night to grow strong and healthy."

Anahit nodded, understanding her father's words. She hugged him tightly and thanked him for the story. From that day on, every time the sun set and the stars came out to play, Anahit thought of the Sun Maiden and her palace of gold and light, and she drifted off to sleep with a smile on her face.

The end.

Goodnight my dear, sweet dreams.
